questions.text:
A 28-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for one week of progressive fatigue, cough and dyspnea, and hemoptysis that occurred today, causing him to call an ambulance. He has no significant medical history and takes no medication. He has smoked a pack per day for 8 years. He is unable to speak in full sentences, so additional history is limited. Temperature is 37 ºC (98.6 °F), heart rate is 130/min, blood pressure is 102/62 mmHg, respiratory rate is 34/min, and oxygen saturation is 84% on room air. The patient appears diaphoretic and pale. Accessory muscles are used during respiration. Auscultation of the lungs reveals crackles diffusely in the bilateral lung fields. Laboratory values are shown below. Chest X-ray reveals diffuse bilateral interstitial opacities. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory study     Result    
 Creatinine     2.7 mg/dL    
 Antinuclear antibodies (ANA)     Negative    
 Anti-myeloperoxidase (anti-MPO) antibodies     Negative    
 Antiproteinase-3 antibodies     Negative    
 Anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) antibodies     Positive    
 Urinalysis     3+ blood    3+ protein    Numerous erythrocytes and erythrocyte casts
questions.solution:
This young, previously healthy patient presents with hemoptysis and acute respiratory distress. He is found to have diffuse, bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray, indicative of diffuse alveolar hemorrhage. Additionally, his laboratory studies reveal evidence of kidney injury and anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies (anti-GBM), consistent with anti-GBM disease, (also referred to as Goodpasture disease). He has significant hypoxemia and impending respiratory failure. The immediate priority is to secure the airway and ensure adequate oxygenation and ventilation, which requires endotracheal intubation.        

If a patient is presenting acutely with signs and symptoms suggestive of an underlying vasculitis, it is critical to perform an ABCDE (airway, breathing, circulation, disability, exposure) assessment. Unstable patients require emergent interventions, which may include securing the airway, obtaining IV access, and initiating continuous vital sign monitoring. Additional measures will depend on the clinical situation. Once the patient is stabilized, further testing to determine the underlying vasculitis can be performed. Initial testing typically includes obtaining a complete blood count (CBC), comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP), erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), c-reactive protein (CRP), and urinalysis, which will help determine if an inflammatory condition is present and the extent of organ involvement. More specific tests, such as ANCA, ANA, and anti-GBM antibodies, can be ordered to help make the diagnosis, but results will take time to come back.    

Option Analysis

❌ High-dose corticosteroids:
Incorrect: While high-dose corticosteroids are used in the treatment of anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease to reduce inflammation and immune response, they do not address the immediate need for airway management and oxygenation in this patient with respiratory failure from hemoptysis.
❌ Plasmapheresis:
Incorrect: Plasmapheresis is an important treatment for removing circulating anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) antibodies from the blood, but it is not an emergency intervention for acute respiratory distress and impending respiratory failure from hemoptysis.  
❌ Cyclophosphamide:
Incorrect: Cyclophosphamide is an immunosuppressive agent used to treat anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease. However, it does not provide immediate relief for respiratory distress. Airway management must be addressed first in this patient. 
✅ Endotracheal intubation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Renal biopsy:
Incorrect: While a renal biopsy is useful for diagnosing anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease by identifying characteristic linear IgG deposits along the glomerular basement membrane, it is not an urgent intervention for this patient in acute respiratory distress and impending respiratory failure from hemoptysis.

questions.text: A two-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with the acute onset of a cough. The parents report that the boy was in his usual state of health until two hours prior to presentation when his mom heard him coughing in the other room. He has continued to cough since. He does not have abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting. He is 40<sup>th</sup> percentile for weight and 35<sup>th</sup> percentile for height. Temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 105/min, respiratory rate is 30/min, blood pressure is 95/60, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, he is well-appearing, in no acute distress, and breathing comfortably. He has a frequent dry cough. Skin exam shows no rashes. On pulmonary exam, there is wheezing localized to the right lung. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This two-year-old boy has an acute cough that came on quickly while his mother was out of the room. He has no signs or symptoms of respiratory distress or hypoxemia and has evidence of wheezing localized to the right lung. This patient’s presentation and his age are consistent with a foreign body aspiration. Bronchoscopy is the most appropriate next step for diagnosis and treatment.

For children presenting with respiratory symptoms, Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability and Exposure (ABCDE) should be assessed. If a patient is unstable, appropriate interventions should be taken, such as stabilizing airway, breathing, and circulation with possible intubation and intravenous fluids. If a patient is stable, then management depends on the diagnosis. When lower airway obstruction is present, the patient may have hypoxemia and/or respiratory distress. In these situations, oxygen and mechanical ventilation should be given as needed. Lower airway obstruction can also cause diffuse wheezing, such as during an asthma exacerbation, and albuterol is appropriate.

Foreign body aspiration most commonly occurs in children younger than two years old, and it can be life threatening. In witnessed episodes of cough and choking, the diagnosis is clear. With large objects, the obstruction may occur higher up and patients may present with stridor and respiratory distress. If the event is not witnessed and there is lower airway obstruction, signs can be more subtle, including acute onset coughing. On physical exam, patients may have localized wheezing or the unilateral absence of breath sounds. Obstruction typically occurs in the right lung since the right mainstem bronchus is wider and runs more vertically than the left mainstem bronchus. When foreign body aspiration is suspected based on clinical findings, bronchoscopy can be both diagnostic and therapeutic with the removal of the foreign body.  

Option Analysis

❌ Albuterol:
Incorrect: Albuterol is the appropriate treatment for asthma. Despite wheezing heard on lung exam in this patient, his presentation is more consistent with a foreign body aspiration given the acute onset of cough and localization of wheezing to the right lung.  
❌ IM epinephrine:
Incorrect: IM epinephrine is the appropriate treatment for anaphylaxis. Patients with anaphylaxis typically present with severe respiratory symptoms and distress and hypoxemia in severe cases. Facial swelling and abdominal discomfort with nausea and vomiting may also be seen with anaphylaxis, all of which are absent in this case.  
❌ Amoxicillin:
Incorrect: Amoxicillin would be the appropriate treatment for community-acquired pneumonia. This patient is afebrile with an acute-onset cough, making pneumonia unlikely. If this patient had pneumonia, it would be expected that he would have developed a cough over days, not hours, and crackles would be more likely on exam.  
❌ Supplemental oxygen:
Incorrect: This patient is not in respiratory distress and does not have hypoxemia; therefore, he does not require supplemental oxygen.  
✅ Bronchoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of shortness of breath. He is accompanied by his parent, who states they were eating lunch when their son developed a scratchy sensation in his throat followed by hives and facial swelling. His medical history is notable for eczema and seasonal allergies. Temperature is 36 °C (98.6 °F), heart rate is 130 beats/minute, blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 28/min with SaO2 of 82% on room air. On exam, the patient is audibly wheezing, using accessory muscles of respiration. His speech is garbled, and he cannot speak in clear, full sentences. Oropharyngeal exam reveals swollen lips and tongue. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This child presents to the emergency department in respiratory distress secondary to anaphylaxis. He is hypotensive, tachycardic, hypoxic, and therefore, unstable due to shock. He likely has a significant amount of tongue and upper airway edema and can no longer protect his airway. Intubation and mechanical ventilation should be performed immediately. IM epinephrine should be given to treat the underlying anaphylactic shock. There are NO absolute contraindications to epinephrine in the setting of anaphylaxis.       

In an unstable patient with suspected airway obstruction from anaphylaxis, attention should be focused first on airway, breathing, circulation, and mentation. The lips, tongue, and oropharynx should be assessed for angioedema, and a mentating patient should be asked to speak their name to be evaluated for associated periglottic or glottic swelling. The skin should be examined for urticaria or angioedema, which if present would help confirm the diagnosis. If the upper airway does not appear edematous, the patient should be placed in the recumbent position, with the lower extremities elevated to maximize perfusion of vital organs.   

Option Analysis

❌ 1L normal saline bolus   :
Incorrect: Airway stabilization is the immediate priority for this patient who presents with anaphylactic shock. He should be intubated and given IM epinephrine. A rapid infusion of normal saline at 20 mL/kg can then be started.  
❌ Albuterol  :
Incorrect: Albuterol can be used to treat bronchospasm that is resistant to intramuscular epinephrine, but first, this patient's airway should be stabilized with intubation and mechanical ventilation. 
✅ Intubation and mechanical ventilation :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Methylprednisolone :
Incorrect: This patient with anaphylactic shock should be emergently stabilized with intubation and mechanical ventilation and IM epinephrine should be administered. Methylprednisolone can be used as an adjunct treatment to reduce inflammation. 
❌ Diphenhydramine :
Incorrect: Diphenhydramine can be utilized as the primary treatment for non-anaphylactic allergic reactions, only used as an adjunct in patients with anaphylactic shock, and it should be given only after the airway has been stabilized and IM epinephrine is given.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old woman is currently in the intensive care unit due to severe Gram-negative sepsis. Despite resuscitative efforts, the patient needs central venous access for the administration of vasopressors. The patient is prepped, draped, and a time-out is called for placement of a triple lumen catheter. After cannulation, the patient is noted to have increased work of breathing. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 121/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 87/60 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 89% on room air. A chest radiograph is obtained and shown below. This surgical error most likely occurred due to cannulation via which of the following anatomic spaces?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Fourth or fifth intercostal space midclavicular line

questions.solution:
This patient undergoes central venous access placement and subsequently develops hemodynamic instability. The chest radiograph demonstrates a pneumothorax with tension physiology combined with tachycardia and hypotension. Thus the triple lumen catheter was likely placed via the superior thoracic aperture, resulting in an iatrogenic tension pneumothorax.  

This area, also known as the thoracic inlet or outlet, is bounded posteriorly by the T1 vertebral body and costovertebral joints, laterally by the first ribs and their costal cartilages, and anteriorly by the superior border of the manubrium. The most commonly injured structures in this anatomic region are the cervical pleura and lung apex. Injuries to the cervical pleura and lung apex can occur via various procedures near the superior thoracic aperture in the neck. Standard procedures in this area include central venous access, pacemaker placement, Swan-Ganz catheter placement, and dialysis catheter placement.  

The pleura is exposed to potential injury from its inferior portion, which descends below the costal margin. The first region is the right part of the infrasternal angle. Surgeries near these areas can result in injury to the lung.  

Option Analysis

✅ Superior thoracic aperture :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lower thoracic aperture :
Incorrect: The lower thoracic aperture is bounded at the inferior aspect of the thorax by the ribs and diaphragm. It is not a potential space for central venous access. 
❌ Femoral triangle:
Incorrect: Central venous catheters can be placed in the groin via the femoral triangle. However, the placement of central catheters in this anatomic location is not associated with iatrogenic pneumothorax. 
❌ Second intercostal space midclavicular line  :
Incorrect: This answer describes the anatomic landmark for needle decompression of a tension pneumothorax. It is not a potential space for central line placement. 
❌ Fourth or fifth intercostal space midclavicular line :
Incorrect: This answer describes the anatomic landmark used to place a chest tube, not a central line.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in an altercation at a bar. He was stabbed multiple times with a pocket knife. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 135/87 mmHg, pulse is 20/min, and respiratory rate is 17/min. Physical examination reveals stab wounds over the anterior chest and left upper extremity. A chest x-ray is obtained and shown below. Which of the following is the primary finding on this patient’s imaging?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient sustained numerous stab wounds. On chest imaging, there is a visible visceral pleural edge with an absence of distal lung markings. In addition, there is subtle leftwards deviation of the mediastinum. These findings are consistent with a diagnosis of pneumothorax.  

Chest x-rays are typically the first-line imaging modality when a pulmonary or mediastinal etiology is suspected. Common indications for chest x-ray include chest pain, shortness of breath, and cough. It is also often used as a part of trauma evaluation (as in the case of this patient).  

Common pathologies and their associated findings on chest x-ray are summarized in the following table:  



Option Analysis

❌ Pneumomediastinum:
Incorrect: Pneumomediastinum presents as linear and curvilinear outlines surrounding the mediastinum. This finding is absent in this patient. In contrast, he has a collapsed right lung, consistent with pneumothorax.
❌ Displaced rib fracture:
Incorrect: This chest radiograph does not demonstrate evidence of a displaced rib fracture.
❌ Clavicular fracture:
Incorrect: The visualized portion of the bilateral clavicles are unremarkable and do not demonstrate evidence of fracture.
❌ Perforated bowel:
Incorrect: Stab wounds can lead to bowel perforation, which can manifest with free air under the diaphragm. In contrast, this patient has a collapsed right lung, which is consistent with pneumothorax.  
✅ Pneumothorax:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old male presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath and chest pain. The patient reports that he was sitting on the couch watching television when the symptoms started. He does not take any medications and is otherwise healthy. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 122/64 mmHg. Respiratory rate is 18/min, and the patient has an oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. Physical examination reveals a tall thin male in no acute distress. A portable chest x-ray is ordered and reveals pleural markings approximately 1-2 centimeters away from the left chest wall. The original image is shown below:  

Image reproduced from

Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is a tall, thin male who developed sudden-onset chest pain and shortness of breath. The vital signs are notable for mild tachycardia. Chest x-ray reveals a small primary spontaneous pneumothorax, which is defined as one wherein the distance between the chest wall and visceral pleural margin is 2 cm or less. Patients with a small pneumothorax and minimal respiratory symptoms can be managed with supplemental 100% oxygen and an observation period of usually six hours. After the observation period, a repeat chest x ray is performed. If the pneumothorax is unchanged or has improved, then the patient is deemed stable for discharge. Most small pneumothoraces will resolve over approximately 7-10 days.  

For larger pneumothoraces (> 2cm distance between the visceral pleura and chest wall) causing prominent respiratory distress, a tube thoracostomy should be performed. This procedure is accomplished by inserting a chest tube at the 4th or 5th space mid axillary line on the affected side. Other indications for chest tube insertion include large traumatic pneumothorax, any pneumothorax with concomitant hemothorax, tension pneumothorax, bilateral pneumothorax, pneumothorax needing ventilator support, or exacerbation of a pneumothorax after conservative therapy.

Option Analysis

✅ 100% FiO2 and observation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Tube thoracostomy:
Incorrect: Chest tube insertion is indicated for any traumatic pneumothorax, pneumothorax with a concomitant hemothorax, tension pneumothorax, or large pneumothorax (> 2 cm away from the chest wall) with significant respiratory symptoms. In contrast, this patient's pneumothorax is not causing respiratory distress and hence can be managed with a more conversative treatment approach.  
❌ Needle decompression:
Incorrect: Needle decompression is indicated for emergent treatment of a tension pneumothorax, which is performed at the second intercostal space, midclavicular line. However, this patient has no risk factors (e.g. penetrating injury) or physical examination findings (e.g., deviated trachea, distended jugular veins) suggestive of a tension pneumothorax.
❌ Video assisted thoracoscopic surgery :
Incorrect: Video assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) is a type of minimally invasive thoracic surgery for correction of large pneumothoraces, hemothorax, or lung resection. In contrast, this patient’s pneumothorax is limited to only the apex of the left lung.
❌ Pericardiocentesis:
Incorrect: Pericardiocentesis is the treatment for cardiac tamponade, a condition characterized by pooling of fluid around the heart. Cardiac tamponade classically presents with the Beck triad (hypotension, raised jugular venous pressure, muffled heart sounds). In contrast, this patient has none of the components of the Beck triad.
